Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Characterizing the Glycoproteome with Effective MS-based Chemical and Enzymatic Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this CAREER award from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program, Professor Ronghu Wu and his group at Georgia Institute of Technology will develop novel analytical methods for the global characterization of glycoproteins in complex biological samples. Protein glycosylation is essential to the survival of eukaryotic cells and is involved in nearly every cellular event. Based on the common features and unique properties of glycans, new strategies integrating chemical and/or enzymatic reactions and modern mass spectrometry-based proteomics techniques will be designed to specifically and comprehensively analyze glycoproteins. The proposed methods will provide a unique opportunity to systemically study the regulation of protein secretion by glycosylation in yeast cells, which will result in an in-depth understanding of the functions of protein glycosylation. The newly developed methods will find extensive applications in biological and biochemical research communities and promote the progress of glycoscience.

The proposed research could have a major impact in the field of glycoprotein studies and in the biology/biochemistry research community in general. The proposed research and educational activities will also provide graduate and undergraduate students, including those from historically underrepresented groups, training opportunities in this highly interdisciplinary research including analytical chemistry, chemical biology, instrumentation and large-scale data analysis. In addition, through Georgia Tech's Center for Education Integrating Science, Mathematics and Computing, the PI and his group will actively participate in outreach activities with high school chemistry teachers and students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Both sugar and protein are very important biological molecules. When a sugar molecule is chemically bound to protein, it is called protein glycosylation, which is one of the most common protein modifications. This modification plays extremely important roles in human cells because it often determines protein structures and activities, and it regulates many cellular events such as cell-cell communication. Aberrant protein glycosylation events are hallmarks of human diseases including cancer and infectious diseases. Therefore, glycoproteins can serve as biomarkers for disease detection and drug targets for disease treatment.

Despite the importance of glycoproteins, global analysis of protein glycosylation in complex biological samples has been a daunting task. In this project, we have mainly focused on the development of novel mass spectrometry (MS)-based methods for comprehensive analysis of protein glycosylation. Although modern MS technology provides a possibility to globally analyze protein modifications, it is still extraordinarily challenging to comprehensively characterize protein glycosylation. This is due to the low abundance of many glycoproteins, the diverse structures of the sugar components in glycoproteins, and the complexity of biological samples. To overcome the challenges, we have developed novel MS-based chemical and enzymatic methods to comprehensively identify and quantify glycoproteins in complex biological samples and target glycoproteins with a particular and important glycan. Furthermore, we have investigated the regulation of glycosylation on protein secretion from cells. The effective analysis methods have extensive applications in the biological and biomedical research fields, which will advance our understanding of glycoprotein functions and the molecular mechanisms of human diseases. These methods will lead to the discovery of glycoproteins as biomarkers for disease detection.

During this project, many graduate and undergraduate students, including those who are underrepresented, have been trained. They have learned knowledge in this multidisciplinary research field, including analytical chemistry, chemical biology, instrumentation, and large-scale data analysis, and have accumulated hands-on research experience. The interactions with high school students and the involvement of their teachers in this project have stimulated their interests in STEM. Training the next generation of scientists has far-reaching positive impacts on society.
